title: Bounding the Circle
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/dbjDIIQGkb-approxpi.JPG?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The area of a circle with radius 1 is equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". One way to determine the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is by inscribing and circumscribing regular polygons. For instance, it is obvious from the drawing above that the circle's area is greater than that of the smaller square but smaller than that of the bigger square. This shows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 < \pi < 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"--using squares we find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" within a range of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4 - 2 = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/nY0X41idyv-approxpi2.JPG?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In the same way, using a circumscribed and an inscribed regular octagon, we find that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2.82842 < \pi < 3.31371"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with a range of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0.48529"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now suppose that instead we inscribe and circumscribe regular 16-gons, obtain the approximation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{insc} < \pi < A_{circsc}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". What is the range of this approximation?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/UK3y1vaA3w-approxpidetail.JPG?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
The area of a circumscribed regular "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-gon consists of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" triangles with width "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 \tan (180^\circ/n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and height 1:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{circsc} = n\cdot \tan \left(\frac{180^\circ}{n}\right)."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The inscribed regular "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-gon can likewise be split into "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" triangles with width "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\sin (180^\circ/n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and height "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cos (180^\circ/n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{insc} = n\cdot \sin \left(\frac{180^\circ}{n}\right) \cos \left(\frac{180^\circ}{n}\right)."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Substituting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = 16"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we find the values
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{circsc} \approx 3.182598; \ \ A_{insc} \approx 3.061467."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Subtraction gives a range of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{0.121130}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Alternatively, the range is equal to
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\cdot \tan \left(\frac{180^\circ}{n}\right) \cdot \sin^2 \left(\frac{180^\circ}{n}\right)."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We generalise it for a regular n-sided polygon. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Range = A_{circsc}  - A_{insc} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \Rightarrow Range = nr^{2} \displaystyle \tan(\frac{\pi}{n}) -  \frac{nr^{2}\displaystyle \sin(\frac{2\pi}{n})}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Substituting n=16 and r=1, we get","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \Rightarrow Range = 16\times \Big( \tan(\frac{\pi}{16}) - \frac{\sin(\frac{\pi}{8})}{2} \Big) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \Rightarrow Range = \boxed{0.121130419} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{insc}=\frac n 2*R_{insc}^2Sin\dfrac{360}n.\\
A_{circsc}=\frac n 2*R_{circsc}^2Sin\dfrac{360}n , ~~but ~1=R_{incsc}=R_{circsc}Cos\dfrac{180}n .\\
\implies~  A_{circsc}=\frac n 2*\left (\dfrac{R_{insc}}{Cos\dfrac{180}n}\right )^2*Sin\dfrac{360}n.\\
\therefore ~ Range=A_{circsc} - A_{insc}=\frac n  2*R_{insc}^2*Sin\dfrac{360}n \left \{ \left (\dfrac 1 {Cos\dfrac{180}n}\right )^2 - 1 \right \}\\
 Range=\frac 1 2*16*1^2*Sin\dfrac{360}{16} \left \{ \left (\dfrac1{Cos\dfrac{180}{16}}\right )^2 - 1 \right \}=.1211304192"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 Followers Problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large \\sum_{k=1}^{35} \\sin \\left(5k^\\circ \\right) = \\tan \\left(\\frac {m}{n}\\right)^\\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The equation above holds true for coprime positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\dfrac {m}{n} < 90"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m+n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} S & = \sum_{k=1}^{35} \sin \left(5k^\circ \right) & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{By Euler's formula: }e^{xi} = \cos x + i \sin x \\ & = \sum_{k=1}^{35} \Im \left[e^{5k^\circ i}\right] & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{where } \Im(z) \text{ is the imaginary part of }z. \\ & = \Im \left[\sum_{k=1}^{35} e^{5k^\circ i}\right] & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{Summation of geometric progression} \\ & = \Im \left[e^{5^\circ i} \left( \frac {1-e^{175^\circ i}}{1-e^{5^\circ i}} \right) \right] \\ & = \Im \left[ \frac {e^{5^\circ i}-e^{180^\circ i}}{1-e^{5^\circ i}} \right] \\ & = \Im \left[ \frac {e^{5^\circ i}+1}{1-e^{5^\circ i}} \right] \\ & = \Im \left[ \frac {1+\cos 5^\circ + i \sin 5^\circ}{1-\cos 5^\circ - i \sin 5^\circ} \right] & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{Multiply up and down with }1-\cos 5^\circ + i \sin 5^\circ \\ & = \Im \left[ \frac {2i \sin 5^\circ}{2-2\cos 5^\circ} \right] \\ & = \frac {\sin 5^\circ}{1-\cos 5^\circ} \\ & = \frac {2\sin 2.5^\circ \cos 2.5^\circ}{1-1 +2\sin^2 2.5^\circ} \\ & = \cot \frac {5^\circ}2 = \tan \frac {175^\circ}2 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies a+b = 175+2 = \boxed{177}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"References:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Euler's formula","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Geometric progression","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

Instead of using the half-angle tangent substitution, maybe it is easier to put "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sin(5^o) = 2 \sin(2.5^o) \cos(2.5^o) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \cos(5^o) = 1 - 2 \sin^2(2.5^o) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Also, when you multply below and above by the conjugate, the result is the imaginary part of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{2i \sin(5^o)}{2 - 2 \cos(5^o)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". There is no "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 - \cos^2(5^o) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" above.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100 Follower Problem! Algebra
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \\neq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be an integer. Find the number of polynomials "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with real coeﬃcients such that, for real "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\Large{\\left( { x }^{ 3 }-m{ x }^{ 2 }+1 \\right) p\\left( x+1 \\right) +\\left( { x }^{ 3 }+m{ x }^{ 2 }+1 \\right) p\\left( x-1 \\right) =2\\left( { x }^{ 3 }-m{ x }^{ 2 }+1 \\right) p\\left( x \\right) }."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}
